Comment: TLDR;  “We don’t do much business with Canada from our standpoint. They do a lot of business with us. We’re at like 4%,” Trump said.  That “4%” figure is wrong. Canada bought about 16% of US goods exports in January, second only to Mexico."

Comment: >  Why would someone invest in anything US made? Honest question.  It's clearly decreasing worldwide. While Trump bloviates about how he doesn't need to do any deals, the Chinese are sitting over there biding their time. Eventually the shelves will run dry. Canada is negotiating trade deals with the EU. Eventually the potash that the US imports from Canada for farm fertilizer will go elsewhere - the US gets 95% of its supply from Canada. Eventually the farms will become a dust bowl. Japan has $1.5T in US treasuries and has threatened to dump it all if the US doesn't remove tariffs. Eventually they and other countries will and the US dollar will tank out of sight. Shipping companies are laying people off. Scarcity will have a real affect on US citizens with food shortages everywhere. Eventually people will wake up to what this dink has done to them but it will be too late.   The isolation of the US will be complete and not at the hands of the Russians or the Chinese but at the hands of the President of the United States and his partners the oligarchs and the Republican Party.
Author: theflower10

Comment: In the current political climate, I see no reason for a foreign company to invest in US made. If we had taken a less hostile approach and instead tried to build industries up in the US with incentives like the Chips act, then, over enough time, I could see the reason.   With the Chips act for example, yes, TSMC would still produce the best semiconductors, and they'd still produce them outside the US. But not every product requires those. Trump could have worked to get more such acts passed, instead he chose to piss all our allies off and destroy our global trade reputation.

Comment: Actually, funny enough, Canada isn't the problem.  Never was.  I'm sure you're shocked.    By the inaccurate measure of deficit/surplus is wrong.  40m Canadians vs 340m Americans is a1: 8.5 ratio.  So for his math to work, for every Canadian, they have to buy 8.5x what an American buys, of american goods.  To even it out.    We actually run in the positive, except when America goes into crazy mode on energy -- oil, gas, electricity.  Cut those out and each Canadian is being more than 8.5 Americans are, in American goods and services.  How do you fix that?  Well, fuck, seriously?  Anyway, Americans cooling it on heat, AC and driving.  We are supplying a need.  But vilified for it.
Author: Postom
